title-group.article-title: Metabolism of Beclomethasone Dipropionate by Cytochrome P450 3A Enzymes

contrib-group.aff: Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, College of Pharmacy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah (J.K.R., C.D.M., G.S.Y., C.A.R.); and Department of Pediatrics, School of Medicine, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah (R.M.W.)

author-notes.corresp: Address correspondence to: Christopher A. Reilly, 30 S 2000 E, Room 201 Skaggs Hall, Salt Lake City, UT 84112. E-mail: chris.reilly@pharm.utah.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2013 by The American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics

abstract.p: Inhaled glucocorticoids, such as beclomethasone dipropionate (BDP), are the mainstay treatment of asthma. However, ∼30% of patients exhibit little to no benefit from treatment. It has been postulated that glucocorticoid resistance, or insensitivity, is attributable to individual differences in glucocorticoid receptor-mediated processes. It is possible that variations in cytochrome P450 3A enzyme-mediated metabolism of BDP may contribute to this phenomenon. This hypothesis was explored by evaluating the contributions of CYP3A4, 3A5, 3A7, and esterase enzymes in the metabolism of BDP in vitro and relating metabolism to changes in CYP3A enzyme mRNA expression via the glucocorticoid receptor in lung and liver cells. CYP3A4 and CYP3A5 metabolized BDP via hydroxylation ([M4] and [M6]) and dehydrogenation ([M5]) at similar rates; CYP3A7 did not metabolize BDP. A new metabolite [M6], formed by the combined action of esterases and CYP3A4 hydroxylation, was also characterized. To validate the results observed using microsomes and recombinant enzymes, studies were also conducted using A549 lung and DPX2 liver cells. Both liver and lung cells produced esterase-dependent metabolites [M1–M3], with [M1] correlating with CYP3A5 mRNA induction in A549 cells. Liver cells produced both hydroxylated and dehydrogenated metabolites [M4, M5, and M6], but lung cells produced only the dehydrogenated metabolite [M5]. These studies show that CYP3A4 and CYP3A5 metabolize BDP to inactive metabolites and suggest that differences in the expression or function of these enzymes in the lung and/or liver could influence BDP disposition in humans.
